title: 109_hr4318
content: The "Outer Continental Shelf Natural Gas Relief Act" terminates prohibitions on expenditures for offshore gas leasing and revokes withdrawals of Federal submerged lands for leasing. It also introduces state approval requirements for gas leasing. The Secretary cannot grant gas leases within 20 miles of a state's coastline without the state's approval. The amendment requires lease sales to offer at least 75% of available unleased acreage in each Outer Continental Shelf planning area. This applies to the current 5-year program and all future programs. Additionally, the Act includes provisions for revenue sharing. The amendment to the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act requires revenue sharing for new gas leases on submerged lands within state boundaries. 40% of bonus bids and royalties go to the state, and 10% is allocated to the Low-Income Home Energy Assistance Program. The Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act amendment mandates revenue sharing for new gas leases on submerged lands within state boundaries. 10-40% of bonus bids and royalties go to the state, based on the fiscal year after enactment. The Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act amendment requires revenue sharing for new gas leases on submerged lands within state boundaries. 10-40% of bonus bids and royalties go to the state, based on the fiscal year after enactment. For leased tracts partially within a state's seaward boundaries, the percentage allocated is based on the surface acreage within those boundaries. The Outer Continental Shelf Natural Gas Relief Act establishes revenue sharing for new federal gas leases, with bonus bids and royalties allocated to states. State seaward boundaries are extended as indicated on specific maps for each outer Continental Shelf region. SEC. 5. NATURAL GAS-ONLY LEASING. Section 8 of the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act is amended to allow for natural gas-only leasing, with regulations defining natural gas, condensate, and oil, establishing lessee rights and obligations, outlining procedures for discovering oil deposits, and setting other appropriate requirements. The Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act is amended to allow for natural gas-only leasing, with regulations applying to existing oil and gas leases. The Secretary may restrict development to natural gas for certain leases, and issue natural gas-only leases without amending the leasing program until June 30, 2007. The Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act is amended to allow for natural gas-only leasing until June 30, 2007, with the Secretary having the authority to issue natural gas-only leases without amending the leasing program for the 5-year period starting in 2007.
